titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Labor Party Records WAG.340
titlestmt.author: Rachel Searcy

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-11-30 15:13:31 -0500.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.unittitle: Labor Party Records

physdesc.extent: in 27 record cartons, 2 manuscript boxes, 1 half manuscript box, 5 flat boxes, and x oversize folders in shared housing.

did.abstract: The Labor Party was an American social democratic political party advocating workers' interests. The party formed in 1996 through a coalition between the United Mine Workers, International Longshore and Warehouse Union, American Federation of of Government Employees, California Nurses Association, other local labor unions, and individual activists. Between 1996 and 2007, the Labor Party launched national campaigns concerning the right to a job, just and equitable access to health care, free higher education, and workers' rights to organize and collectively bargain. The party suspended operations in 2007. This collection consists of materials created and collected by the Labor Party documenting the organization's founding and organizing on behalf of workers' interests in a social democratic framework. Materials in this collection include photographs; reports; newspaper clippings; financial records; administrative records, such as meeting minutes, agendas, membership files, and internal correspondence; records documenting state and local chapters, including applications and correspondence with the national party; convention materials, include programs, ephemera, proceedings, and planning documents; newspapers and newsletters, including the Labor Party News and Labor Party Press; subject and project files for campaigns related to healthcare, workers' safety, labor legislation, coalition-building, and electoral politics; audiovisual recordings on a variety of formats; and party ephemera, including pins, buttons, and other objects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of materials created and collected by the Labor Party (United States, 1996) documenting the organization's founding and organizing on behalf of workers' interests in a social democratic framework. Materials in this collection include photographs; reports; newspaper clippings; financial records; administrative records, such as meeting minutes, agendas, membership files, and internal correspondence; records documenting state and local chapters, including applications and correspondence with the national party; convention materials, include programs, ephemera, proceedings, and planning documents; newspapers and newsletters, including the Labor Party News and Labor Party Press; subject and project files for campaigns related to healthcare, workers' safety, labor legislation, coalition-building, and electoral politics; audiovisual recordings on a variety of formats; and party ephemera, including pins, buttons, and other objects.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by the Labor Party, the creator of this collection, were relinquished and transferred to the public domain in 2017 by Katherine Isaac. These materials are governed by a Creative Commons CC0 license, which permits publication and reproduction of materials accompanied by full attribution. See, https://creativecommons.org/licenses/

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Katherine Isaac and Mark Dudzic, 2018. The accession number associated with this gift is 2018.105.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu, (212) 998-2630 with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Born-digital materials have not been transferred and may not be available to researchers. Researchers may request access copies. To request that material be transferred, or if you are unsure if material has been transferred, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu, (212) 998-2630 with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Labor Party Records; WAG 340; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: 1 large banner, duplicates of Labor Party newspapers and newsletters, and duplicates of ephemera such as stickers and buttons were discarded prior to accessioning.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Labor Party was an American social democratic political party advocating workers' interests. The party formed in 1996 through a coalition between the United Mine Workers, International Longshore and Warehouse Union, American Federation of of Government Employees, California Nurses Association, other local labor unions, and individual activists. Between 1996 and 2007, the Labor Party launched national campaigns concerning the right to a job, just and equitable access to health care, free higher education, and workers' rights to organize and collectively bargain. The Labor Party endorsed independent candidates in local elections in San Francisco (2001), Ohio (2001), and South Carolina (2005-2006). The party suspended operations in 2007.
Labor Party. "About the Labor Party." http://www.thelaborparty.org/a_index.html (retrieved August 1, 2018).
